profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-04-10 19:09:53 -0400.

repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized in three series: Buildings and grounds; Architectural drawings and plans; and Unprocessed accessions.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The first series contains materials originating in the Facilities Department as well as information collected by Russell Miller while preparing his history of Tufts College, Light on the Hill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains photographs, drawings, plans, correspondence, maps, newspaper clippings, and publications about Tufts buildings. The bulk of the material deals with the Medford campus.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Department of Grounds and Buildings was created during the latter half of the nineteenth century, with the purpose of maintaining the grounds and buildings of Tufts College in Medford. As the college grew to include the Schools of Medicine, Dental Medicine, and Veterinary Medicine, responsibility for maintaining the Boston and Grafton Campuses, in addition to the Medford/Somerville Campus, fell to the Department of Grounds and Buildings. The department was renamed the Department of Buildings and Grounds in January 1980. In 1999, the department again underwent a name change, becoming the Tufts University Facilities Department. While still charged with building and ground maintenance, the Facilities Department is also responsible for energy management, recycling, administration of the space inventory system, and planning and implementing maintenance projects.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: University records are closed for 20 years from the date of their creation. Records older than 20 years that do not pertain to student education, staff and faculty employment and Board of Trustees records are open for research. This collection may require review before it is available for use. Please contact DCA for further details.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Copyright to all materials created by Tufts University employees in the course of their work is held by the Trustees of Tufts University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials collected by Russell Miller while preparing his history of Tufts College, Light on the Hill. It contains correspondence, clippings, and photographs primarily of the Medford campus, including maps and plans. The text of a detailed tour of Goddard Chapel is included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A copy of the complete 1970 art inventory currently at the Art Gallery (furniture, art etc) is photocopied in a binder behind the front desk; careful, the 1970 inventory is only a partial inventory of objects on campus at the time.

did.unittitle: Art objects, Treasures of Tufts Exhibit

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of architectural drawings and plans, and artistic renderings of Tufts University buildings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains paintings of a new student residential hall, the Science and Technology Center, the Olin Center for Language and Culture and The Aidekman Art Center. Drawings were originally mounted in foam board and each had a paper label. Mounting was removed and original labels were retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This item was found uncataloged in the stacks in the Spring of 2009. Note its location, it is housed in a box with other oversized materials. Inclued in this item are blurprints for the the Library Dormitory, East Hall, West Hall, Dean Hall, Theological School Dormitory, and the Women's Dormitory. Also included are the rates for the yearly cost of the room for students as well as dormitory regulations. When the bound collection of blueprints was found attached to the first page was a plan for Dean Hall and Curtis Hall on linen. The rusty paperclips attaching the plans to the bound blue prints have been removed.
